CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant gave birth to a girl . She stated to the authorities that the father of the child was a NORP national living in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG heard the applicant on the issue of the paternity of her child .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG appointed ORG as guardian to the child for the purpose of bringing paternity proceedings on her behalf and representing her in such proceedings . The decision stated that it had been taken as the applicant had not filed a paternity action . ORG received the decision on DATE , but it did not bring paternity proceedings . On DATE the ORG admitted , in reply to the applicant ’s complaint , that ORG by its failure to file an action had delayed the case .
CARDINAL . On DATE paternity proceedings were instituted , at the applicant ’s request , before the ORG . On DATE the applicant paid the court fee .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG heard the applicant and decided to transfer the case to ORG for reasons of jurisdiction . The file was submitted to the latter court on DATE .
CARDINAL . A hearing before ORG was held on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the case was assigned to a different judge .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered an official translation of the relevant documents as it was necessary to seek the assistance of NORP authorities . The request for assistance was sent to the competent NORP court on DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG received the reply from the NORP court on DATE . According to it , the defendant had denied the paternity of the applicant ’s child . He declared himself ready to undergo a DNA test . The defendant had also explained that he had been granted asylum in GPE and that he could not travel abroad .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG held a hearing at which the applicant maintained her claim . On DATE ORG appointed an expert in genetics . On DATE the expert informed the applicant that he had not yet made a blood analysis of her daughter as ORG had failed to pay an advance on his costs . The letter further stated that the expert had informed ORG how to obtain a blood sample from the alleged father in GPE . ORG sent the relevant request to the NORP court on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the expert informed ORG that he had not yet received the blood sample from his NORP counter - part . On DATE ORG informed the applicant that the NORP authorities had not yet obtained a blood sample from the alleged father of the child .

CARDINAL . After having made an inquiry from the expert on DATE , ORG again requested the NORP authorities for assistance on DATE . In a reply delivered on DATE the competent NORP court informed ORG that the files relating to its request had already been sent to it . The NORP court enclosed copies of those documents to its reply . It was later established that the original mail from the NORP court had been lost prior to its delivery .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG scheduled a hearing for DATE . It unsuccessfully attempted to have the defendant summoned . On DATE the case was adjourned as the defendant ’s whereabouts were unknown .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG again requested the competent NORP court for assistance in establishing the defendant ’s whereabouts and in obtaining a blood sample from him . It further authorised the expert to proceed with the analysis of samples from the applicant and the child .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG received information about the new address of the defendant .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG again asked the NORP court for assistance in obtaining a blood sample as well as further information about the defendant ’s situation .
CARDINAL . On DATE the expert submitted a DNA analysis of the applicant and her daughter .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG received a reply from the NORP court . It stated that the NORP court had heard the defendant on DATE who had agreed to an analysis of his blood . However , the defendant subsequently had not complied with repeated requests to this effect and had failed to appear for a sample to be taken from him . Under NORP law the defendant could not be obliged to submit a blood sample without his consent . According to the letter , the NORP court could take no further action in that respect . ORG obtained a translation of the above reply on DATE .
CARDINAL . A hearing before ORG was scheduled for DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant complained about the length of the paternity proceedings before ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the complaint as being manifestly ill - founded . The decision stated that the complaint concerned the proceedings before ORG . ORG found undue delays in the proceedings DATE . However , after that period ORG had proceeded with the case in an appropriate manner . In particular , it had sent several requests to a court in GPE on DATE , DATE , DATE and on DATE . It had further ordered an expert opinion , sent a request for a blood sample to be obtained from the defendant and had the documentary evidence translated . In addition , it had encountered difficulties resulting from the loss of files abroad and the fact that summonses could not be served on the defendant .
CARDINAL . ORG concluded that the overall length of the proceedings could not be imputed to ORG as its proceeding with the case had depended on co - operation with the NORP authorities .
